qas.question: What is the name for lending that entices borrowers to enter into unsafe secured loans?
What company used a classic bait-and-switch method by advertising low interest rates?
Which type loan would the consumer be put into instead of the 1% or 1.5% interest rate loan as advertised?
What was created when the interest charged was greater than the amount of interest paid?
What type predatory lending method did Countrywide Financial use?

context: <a0_0>Predatory lending<a0_0/> refers to the practice of unscrupulous lenders, enticing borrowers to enter into "unsafe" or "unsound" secured loans for inappropriate purposes. A <a4_0>classic bait-and-switch<a4_0/> method was used by <a1_0>Countrywide Financial<a1_0/>, advertising low interest rates for home refinancing. Such loans were written into extensively detailed contracts, and swapped for more expensive loan products on the day of closing. Whereas the advertisement might state that 1% or 1.5% interest would be charged, the consumer would be put into an <a2_0>adjustable rate mortgage (ARM)<a2_0/> in which the interest charged would be greater than the amount of interest paid. This created <a3_0>negative amortization<a3_0/>, which the credit consumer might not notice until long after the loan transaction had been consummated.
